item.title: Some Java Tuts
item.dc:creator: @MoparUnited MoparUnited
item.description:
@MoparUnited wrote:

yea, i’m going to be blunt however you will eventually learn a little from these tuts, those dont are well… :rolleyes: you know what i mean…

1. so what the hell do i have to do to make a java program…
start of paining attention!

[code]public class theclass {
public static void main(Strings[] args) {
System.out.println(“Yay my first fricken java application”);//the message executed…
}//last brace of method

}//finishing class brace[/code]

well now some of you will probably expect me to explain…
all there is to it is simply the class(theclass) it mush be saved as .java as a java extention…again for those who don’t know well… :rolleyes:
the next well we should consider remembering…how the hell are we going to run the fricken class without the main method…
we then have to simply see if the method has been established properly…we simply do this by adding the wonderful “System.out.println(”");".

2.how exactly can i instance stuff…
let me explain…instance where i come from, lets just put means to for example a method in a java file called method1, you would like to use this method in another java file. Instancing allows us do make this true…
req: 2 java files…brain…
first class…

public class classA { public classA() { System.out.println("It works..."); } }
right lets make another class shall we…
one more thing…don’t forget to end the method as well as the class…thats just common sense…

public class finalClass { public static void main(String[] args) { new classA(); } }
alrighty…lets take a step back…
obviously there is something different here…there 2 classes involved…
the “classA” is the class that gets instanced…or rather the constructor gets instanced…
the “finalClass” extracts the method from “classA”… your probably wondering why the hell do i need to instance while i can make my own method in the same fricken class… here is the most common reason…lol…it looks more intellectual… or fancy…however you are very right, it really does not matter, either way you still make work…! :D…
lets move on…
3.
…lets discuss some ways on how to make messaging a lot more…well…handled…
we can start by using the strings…hooray!..lol…

public static String MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE = "Great it's another message";

this is where instancing comes in handy… sometimes… ;D
lets make another one of our classes again shall we?..

[code]public class classA {
public static String MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE = “Great it’s another message”;

public static void main(String[] args) {
System.out.println(MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE);
}
}[/code]
explationation…time…as you see clearly here…that the way we instance the message_yes_message here is through the string… now one great probably he best…however sometimes the worse reason is that…it…helps…save…up…space…and memory, don’t forget memory…
…now lets use a class to instance the entire thang…

public class classA { public static String MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE = "Great it's another message"; }
right…thats it think about it for the class…lets finish of…

public class finalClass { public static void main(String[] args) System.out.println(classA.MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE); } }
right…right…whats goin on…? well we can see perfectly that we have “borrowed” the string “MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE” from classA…
we have instance yet once again… :P…
4. LEETS…MOVE ON…
here’s the code, i will explain…later…on…
JUST LOOK, AND OBSERVE…

[code]public static int lol = 0;//its an int…remember that 

public static String MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE = "Great another message";
public static String MESSAGE_NO_MESSAGE = "No another message";


public static void main() {
	if(lol == 0) {
	System.out.println(MESSAGE_YES_MESSAGE);
	lol = 1;
	} else if(lol == 1) { 
		System.out.println(MESSAGE_NO_MESSAGE);
	}
}

}
[/code]
…you now know the basics of the basics on how to simply…create a java file and make it work…these are the if and else statements…
…lets start of with a definition…gets everybody going :)…these if and else statements are one of the basics of all the control flow statements…these if-else “statements” only launch the program “if”, well the value in this case it is set to “0” is true…you can find several other explainations at…the specific link at the bottom…

http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/if.html// the great site which explains perfectly what exactly these statements are…now comming back to this code…lets discuss other codes involved here…now if you looook very…carefully you will spot a code looking like this…“lol = 1;” this simple little code tells the “if” to change its value…straight away to, in this case “1”, now…moving on you will spot the “else if” that comes next…and look…look…at its value…it is set to 1…this means it is “true”…it will execute immediately…the rest…well should know now…closes the entire method and the classes…braces…thanks for your time… :o

~MoparUnited~

Read full topic
